title: Year of the sad horse: Factory mistake creates viral toy in China | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Last year, so-called "ugly cute" toys like Labubu dolls took the world by storm. Now, with Lunar New Year just weeks away, a manufacturing error has produced a new contender that will turn any frown upside-down. Manny Tsigas reports. #ABCTheWorld #ABCAsiaPacific  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Trump administration defends killing man in Minneapolis, contradicts videos | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The Trump administration has again gone on the defensive after another American citizen was fatally shot by immigration agents in Minneapolis. Federal officials allege the victim, Alex Pretti, attacked the officers, labelling him a would-be assassin. Charles Kuck, an immigration lawyer based in Tennessee, tells The World it's probably not going to be the last death at the hands of ICE as the unrest continues. title: Myanmar's junta leader dismisses critics as allies head for landslide win | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The final round of voting has now closed in Myanmar in what's been a controversial first general election in the country since a military-backed coup ousted Aung San Suu Kyi in 2021. United Nations officials have labelled the election "illegitimate" as a violent civil war continues to rage across Myanmar. David Mathieson, an independent analyst based in Thailand, tells The World Myanmar's election results were already a foregone conclusion. title: Bangladesh election: Campaigning begins as Sheikh Hasina slams poll in India  | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Campaigning in Bangladesh's election is underway as voters prepare to cast their ballots on the 12th of February. It's also the first election since Sheikh Hasina was ousted from power following a youth-led uprising stemming from a deadly crackdown against anti-government protesters in 2024. So what can we expect from these elections? Dr Mubashar Hasan, an expert on Bangladeshi politics from Western Sydney University spoke to The World's Girish Sawlani about who is likely to emerge victorious. title: Man arrested after suspected explosive thrown into Invasion Day rally in Perth | ABC NEWS
description: A 31-year-old man has been arrested amid an investigation into a suspected explosive device thrown at the stage of an Invasion Day rally in Perth.  A crime scene has been set up at the man’s home in Warwick as police gather more information.  Western Australia’s Police Commissioner Col Blanch says the device contains ball bearings, screws and an unidentified liquid.  The state's Premier Roger Cook expressed his concerns about the attack. title: South-eastern Australia braces for record heat | ABC NEWS
description: Large parts of Victoria, inland New South Wales and South Australia are bracing for record temperatures as a prolonged heatwave grips Australia’s southeast.  Adelaide is on track to record the warmest night ever, while Melbourne is forecast to peak at 45 degrees. Ouyen and Mildura could potentially see the hottest day since the Black Summer bushfires in 2009 with temperatures likely to notch 49 degrees.  Residents have been ordered to evacuate from bushfires in the Otways region. title: Trump’s bid to control the Western Hemisphere | ABC News Daily podcast
description: Donald Trump says he needs Greenland.    He’s suggested he could buy it and he threatened tariffs on nations that didn’t support his quest to take it.    Now he’s dropped the tariff threat after negotiations and he’s ruled out using military force.    The US president’s approach to Greenland might be erratic but it’s all in line with his foreign policy aim to reorder the world.    Today, Monica Duffy Toft from the Fletcher School at Tufts University on Trump’s bid to control the Western Hemisphere.   Featured:    Monica Duffy Toft, Professor of International Politics and Director of the Center for Strategic Studies at the Fletcher School at Tufts University in Boston

title: Donald Trump and Tim Walz hold 'productive' talks about ICE in Minnesota | ABC NEWS
description: A phone call between Donald Trump and Minnesota governor Tim Walz is signaling that the Trump administration could rein in its immigration crackdown in Minneapolis following the shooting death of a second US citizen by federal agents. Trump and Walz said they were willing to work together and the administration is sending border czar Tom Homan to the state. A federal judge has also heard arguments from state lawyers who want the number of federal agents reduced. title: Gold Coast light plane crash leaves two with life-threatening injuries | ABC NEWS
description: Two people are fighting for their lives after a light plane crash on the Gold Coast.  Emergency services responded to reports of smoke billowing after an aircraft crash at the Heck Field airport near Jacobs Well.  First responders are facing difficulty accessing the area which is surrounded by sugar cane plantations. title: Remains of last Israeli hostage found in Gaza cemetery | ABC NEWS
description: The remains of the last Israeli hostage held in Gaza has been found after a major search operation inside the IDF’s yellow line in the strip.  24-year-old police officer Ran Gvili was killed in a deadly rampage by Hamas militants on October 7th, before his body was transported and hidden in the enclave. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has hailed the discovery as an ‘extraordinary achievement’, while Hamas claims it assisted Israeli authorities in the search effort.  The retrieval has put more pressure on the Israeli government to return the remains of deceased Palestinians and open the Rafah border crossing to allow aid into the war-ravaged strip. title: Ferret racing a hit at annual Tasmanian festival | ABC News
description: Ferret racing is one of the biggest drawcards at the Henley on Mersey festival, which runs on January 26th in Tasmania's north-west town Latrobe. title: Trump signals willingness to dial back ICE operation after Walz call | ABC NEWS
description: The White House has floated the possibility of reining in its immigration crackdown in Minnesota, after US President Donald Trump hailed a ‘positive’ phone call with the state’s governor Tim Walz about two fatal shootings of US citizens by ICE agents. The Trump administration has deployed border czar Tom Homan and signalled it would eventually withdraw federal immigration agents from Minneapolis. Former US president Bill Clinton has accused the Trump administration of being dishonest with the American people, while the National Rifle Association reaffirmed the right of US citizens to bear arms. title: China's top general investigated as Xi Jinping continues corruption purge | ABC NEWS
description: Xi Jinping's anti-corruption drive has taken on new meaning after he removed his long-term ally and army chief Zhang Youxia amid a probe into his conduct. Neil Thomas from the Asia Society Policy Institute says the general may have been caught up in corruption when he headed up the PLA's procurement program, or could have been using his considerable influence to protect a corruption network. title: Donald Trump sends 'border czar' Tom Homan to Minnesota | ABC NEWS
description: Donald Trump will send his "border czar" Tom Homan to Minnesota, as Republicans have joined Democrats in demanding a fuller investigation into the fatal shooting of nurse Alex Pretti by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents in Minneapolis.  The US president said his administration was "reviewing everything", but insisted he had confidence in Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem and that ICE agents had "done a phenomenal job".  Mr Pretti's death has sparked a wave of anger and protests in the US, and is the second fatal shooting in Minneapolis involving federal law enforcement this month. title: What do you tell your friends amidst childcare investigation | ABC NEWS
description: Adele Ferguson is an investigative journalist who's been looking into the childcare sector over the last year.  Ferguson has uncovered a pattern of abuse and mistreatment, so what can families do to keep their children safe?  Reporting by Amal Wehbe, ABC News Social Media Team. Filmed by Sissy Reyes.  Counselling and support services: 1800 Respect, National counselling helpline: 1800 737 732 Bravehearts, counselling and support for survivors of child sexual abuse: 1800 272 831 Lifeline, 24-hour crisis support and suicide prevention: 13 11 14 Kids Helpline on 1800 551 800 Headspace on 1800 650 890 (children and young people) ReachOut at au.reachout.com (children and young people)  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad.
